componenttext: Thank you, Amy. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2010 third quarter ended December 31, 2009. This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not statements of facts or guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed in these statements.For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see risk factors and management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and the results of operations in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2009, and in the company's quarterly reports on Form 10-Q.This morning's call will include remarks from Mark Fetting, our Chairman and CEO; and Mr. CJ Daley, our CFO, who will discuss Legg Mason's financial results. In addition, following a review of the company's quarter, we will then open the call to Q&A. Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Mark Fetting. Mark?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. In 2009, we initiated a turnaround at Legg Mason, and I am pleased with most of our progress. Our balance sheet is much stronger, investment performance has improved across virtually all key affiliates, and
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. In 2009, we initiated a turnaround at Legg Mason, and I am pleased with most of our progress. Our balance sheet is much stronger, investment performance has improved across virtually all key affiliates, and our focus on distribution is paying some market share dividends.2010 was kicked off here in Baltimore with all of our key sales teams and our investment managers coming together to start the new year strong. We are ready to take advantage of opportunities this year. But to be clear, more progress needs to be made in restoring growth and improving margins. As we look at the markets, we believe general trends should show a gradual move in assets from money market funds and taxable fixed income to equities and alternatives as the credit market stall further and as investors' risk appetite increase. In the wake of the rally of the most-beaten-down stocks in '09, many of our equity managers in the U.S. see the most value and the greatest opportunity in high-quality companies with strong balance sheets, steady earnings and high returns on capital. Our team at Western [Western Asset Management] believes that a slow recovery in the economy will continue in the first half of 2010. Housing prices seem to have bottomed, unemployment shows signs of moderating and production is coming back online to meet demand.Continued challenges with some balance sheet issues and budget issues and state and local governments continue to draw a caution, but by in large, Western still sees value in the market. The alternative sector went to a significant clean-up period last year. And the remaining players are stronger. Investors have become more comfortable with the sector, as there is now more transparency and generally less leverage being applied. Permal, our fund of hedge funds manager, has seen more interest from high net worth in institutional clients, with Asia being a particularly attractive opportunity. Strategically, as I look forward for Legg Mason in our global asset management industry, I am very encouraged, particularly by the visits with clients, consultants and distribution partners I had over the last quarter across the globe: In Europe, in Asia and throughout the Americas. I believe clients are all about more scrutiny, more due diligence, an increased appreciation for specialized skills for specialized mandates. Yes, there is an important shift in passive and ETF, some of which I believe is cyclical coming out of the crisis, and some are secular, which we'll have to follow and potentially participate in. But active remains the dominant choice, and this bodes well for our franchise firms.Western's scale and specialization skill set, Royce's expertise in small and micro-cap investing Permal's preeminence in fund of hedge funds, Legg Mason Capital Management in ClearBridge and large-cap U.S. equities among other specializations and Batterymarch and Brandywine. So with that as a backdrop, let's turn to the financial highlights onto the deck that we distributed this morning. Let's start with Page 2.As you can see, revenues are up 5% over the last quarter to $690 million, primarily due to higher performance fees at Western and Permal, higher average assets under management and a greater percentage of equity assets in our mix. Operating income, as adjusted, was $92 million as higher revenues were more than offset by the previously disclosed $28 million real estate lease charge for our sub-leasing efforts. Our operating margin, as adjusted this quarter, was 17.9%. The impact of the real estate lease charge on the operating margin, as adjusted, was 5.5%. So excluding the effect of the accelerated charge for subleasing all of our excess space in our headquarters, operating margin would've been up a couple of percentage points. Net income was almost $45 million or $0.28 a share, which includes $0.11 for the real estate. Cash income on an adjusted basis was $93 million or $0.57 per diluted share. EBITDA, as adjusted, was $165 million, up 20% from the prior-quarter level.Let's take a look at Assets Under Management as we turn to Slide 3. Here, as you can see and as we discussed early in December, there is a pick up in outflows. Assets Under Management were $682 billion, down from the $703 billion in September, driven by the higher outflows and partially offset by market appreciation. Equity assets are a higher percentage of the total mix at 25%. This is the highest level since September quarter of '08. Average AUM was up in the third quarter as compared with the previous, just over 1%.Let's turn to Slide 4 in the key issue of net flows. As reported and discussed earlier, there was an uptick in the December quarter, driven by year-end reallocation decisions made by investors. Some took advantage of the strong performance rebound across several of our affiliates to make changes. Fixed income outflows for the quarter were approximately $24 billion. Equity increased to $4 billion and liquidity were $5 billion out. You will recall that last quarter we had positive liquidity flows of $4 billion in a quarter where the industry had record outflows. This quarter, we were slightly better than the industry outflow trend. In the fixed income area, some investors who earlier in the year had been assessing the risk they had in their fixed income portfolios did take advantage of a sharply stronger performance in the calendar year and made a change. In addition, Western experiences a fair amount of seasonality in the December quarter. And as we've mentioned before, investors are moving out of the enhanced cash area in particular. To be clear and specific, there is a single client representing about $5 billion of that outflows in the enhanced cash area, something that we hadn't [ph] been expecting for some time. And that area which was over $20 billion, just a bit more than a year ago, is now down to $3 billion and this is consistent with the industry experience across the board.If you kind of acknowledge the enhanced cash situation and look at other areas, you'll see, really, individual asset-allocation decisions across the globe. There was a bit of a moving out of limited-duration portfolios, particularly those that use spread products that were part of the process. But overall, what we see is, really, clearly some issues that we've been talking about and an expectation of some lumpiness, but at the same time, as we'll discuss, some good activity on the upbeat.So let's turn, if we can, to our affiliates. The reminder, and this is on Slide 5, as we've done in the past, we're listing the affiliates in the order of their contribution to earnings. So let's focus on Western first, our largest manager, with $481 billion under management. We do see the outflows continuing to be an issue, but we do think that this quarter, because of the seasonality and some of the specific client situations, may not be projectable. Important to Western returning to net inflows will be continued strong performance and the continued decrease of volatility in the fixed income markets. We do see an uptick in RFP activity, and while there's always a lag between activity inflows, that is encouraging. We absolutely see continued interest in the Brazilian, Australian, Pan Asian local currency products, their emerging market debt products, their global credit products and global tips.Most importantly, clients are pleased with how the additions in the investment and risk management teams have taken place. And Western believes that the changes they made in their investment process are working well. And as we've discussed, their performance has been strong this year.Let's go to Permal where assets were slightly lower at almost $18 billion. Performance at Permal is was strong across the board, with 75% of their asset subject to performance fees above their high-water mark. Permal is one of the industry players poised to serve the growing separate account market in the alternative space. Legg Mason is providing Permal with an increased level of back-office support, representing a good example of our affiliates can leverage our corporate infrastructure.Next is ClearBridge, our largest equity affiliate, who saw assets increase to $53.5 billion. ClearBridge is seeing some initial interest in the strategies from the family and high net worth offices, and we're embarking on a comprehensive road show with our wholesalers to the independent advisor channel this quarter, as they continue to see greater penetration in new channels. In December, ClearBridge was selected by Pax World and Morningstar as the sub-advisor across four asset classes in their new socially-responsible offerings. Assets at Royce grew to just over $30 billion. They continue to see inflows this quarter amidst continued strong performance across the complex. Brandywine, assets were about $29 billion with modest outflows for the quarter. Fixed income performance here rebounded nicely, and their flagship global fixed income investment grade product is ahead of its benchmark over the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods, and we continue to work with Brandywine to source the opportunities through our sales team, one institutional mandate for the large-cap value equity product funded in the quarter, and another one in the quarter funded last week, both of these totaling over $300 million. Brandywine is also seeking client wins in Japan, working with the LM Japan office.Batterymarch was essentially flat at $20 billion. Batterymarch's global emerging markets product is seeing strong relative performance in the second half of '09 as the markets have moved from a rally in the most beaten down stocks to higher-quality names. Interest in the product is building among consultants. Finally, Legg Mason Capital Management assets were up slightly to about $17 billion with continued strong performance. Four of their six mutual funds had top decile performance for the year, and all six were top quartile according to Lipper. Legg Mason Capital Management had modest inflows into their offshore funds, an important [indiscernible], some out floor in the U.S. funds, and incisional clients are inviting them back into RFPs.We shift to Slide 6 with focus on long-term performance. You can see, clearly, the progress we have made this year with regard to performance and how that is playing into our longer-term numbers. Over two-thirds of our long-term fund assets are beating their benchmark over the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods. If you go to Slide 7, you can look at the break up between equity and fixed income. With equity, the performance has picked up in the one year, but especially in the three and five year. On fixed income, it is even more impressive with the fixed income funds in the top quartile for the one-year period, the funds are also beating the Lipper averages in the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods, up from extremely low levels in those same periods a year ago.Let's shift, if we can, to distribution. Slide 8, you can see that net sales in our Americas distribution group shows improvement over our year-ago period, although we did see a reversal in flow trends this quarter as sub-advisory accounts, particularly a variable annuity clients, made some decisions to shift to other asset classes. Growth sales, one measure of measuring our performance, are up sharply in Americas distribution. Retail funds sales against the prior year are strong and is actually at an all-time high in the very important independent advisory channel. Institutional sales were up over 40% as compared with the year-ago period. And as I mentioned previously, we're seeing some share gains in certain categories of funds, muni and equity in particular.We raised our third closed-end fund with Western this quarter. Raising $316 million in the global corporate fund, this is our largest closed-end fund offering during '09, where we had several strong product introductions.The retirement channel is going to be an important market for us. We will tap into our affiliate expertise and add to our existing income and dividend-generating products. We are launching an inflational-where-tactical asset allocation program in February, designed to be not highly correlated to the broader markets. And we think it will be very attractive for retirement portfolio.On Slide 9, we focused on international distribution, which showed continued improvement compared with the same period a year ago, positive for the fiscal year. This was the best quarter in the last five of our International Distribution group led by Japan, where Legg Mason has been established the longest. We also saw net positive flows in Europe, the Americas and Asia this quarter. The majority of flows outside of the U.S. continue to be centered on fixed income in Western. The bulk of our net inflows on the equity side are going into Royce, Legg Mason Capital Management and Congruix, our Asian equity manager. We launched the Legg Mason Permal Global Absolute Fund in October and has subsequently registered it in Europe and Asia. So now I will give it to C.J. to cover the financial issues. C.J.?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Mark indicated, we're continuing to see improved trends in investment performance, which resulted in higher revenues this quarter, primarily performance fees. So in December, revenues grew 5% from the September
componenttext: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Mark indicated, we're continuing to see improved trends in investment performance, which resulted in higher revenues this quarter, primarily performance fees. So in December, revenues grew 5% from the September quarter as a result of higher average AUMs, and as I mentioned, a substantial pick up in performance fees. On the expense side, we recorded the entire sublease charge for our headquarters of $28 million that we announced on the call last quarter. Although, we did expect that the charge would come in over several quarters, we were able to complete all the sublease transactions this quarter, so we took the entire $28 million charge that we had highlighted last quarter. That charge reduced our reported diluted earnings by $28 million or $0.11 per share.In addition, subsequent to the end of the quarter, as anticipated after the net operating loss, tax law changed to allow us to put tax losses back five years instead of three. We received a tax refund in early January of $459 million, which increased our total cash position to $1.9 billion and our excess cash to $1.5 billion. With that excess cash, we announced today that we paid down $550 million term loan, which was scheduled to mature in October of 2010 this year. The reduction of the outstanding debt will lower our annual interest expense by approximately $15 million or $0.06 per share.So let's move on to the investor deck on Slide 10. Our GAAP earnings per share were $0.28 per share or $45 million, and that includes $28 million in real estate lease loss charges that we took. Cash income, as adjusted, was $0.57 per share or $93 million. It also reflects the impact of the lease losses. Cash income was higher this quarter, but on a per-share basis was slightly lower due to a higher share count this quarter related to the equity unit exchanges that we completed in August.Our operating margin, as adjusted, was 18%, down from 21% last quarter. The lease charge impact on the operating margin was 5.5 percentage points. The margin improvement, including lease loss was a result of higher revenues, particularly performance fees, with relatively flat operating expense.Operating revenues for the quarter were $690.5 million, an increase of 5%, primarily due to the higher performance fees at Western and Permal, and as well as higher Assets Under Management in the quarter. As we discussed it last quarter's call, we continue to see modest increases in fee waivers required in our Money Fund business, and we expect this to continue into the next several quarters. For modeling, our expectation is that any increase in waivers for the next quarter would only be a few million dollars grossed or less than $0.01 a share.Moving on to Slide 11, to break out our operating expenses, we're up 5%. But the entire increase, as you can see, is driven by the lease charge. Excluding that item, total expenses were essentially flat compared to the prior quarter. Comp and benefits expensed for $288 million in both the December and September quarters, while the increase in distribution and servicing expense was the result of successful global fixed income closed-end fund launch this quarter and the related expenses of about $4.3 million.Occupancy expense increase was driven by the real estate charge related to our headquarters built. With the finalization of the subleasing of our headquarters' vacant space, we have now either reserved or sublet at all of our excess space. Strategically, we have moved aggressively on while reserving and subletting our excess space. And as a result, beginning next quarter, because of our headquarters' sublease completion, our occupancy cost will be down approximately $800,000 per quarter or $3.2 million per year. This is in addition to savings of $300,000 we received this quarter, as we realized the partial period of the headquarters' sublease benefits. All the remaining expense categories showed improvement over the sequential quarter due to our continued focus on cost maintenance and discipline.On Slide 12, we highlight our compensation and benefits expenses expressed as a percentage of net revenues, which are operating in revenues less our distribution servicing expenses to third parties. Our compensation ratio of 53% is slightly lower than last quarter's level due to our higher revenues and our cost discipline. With the current revenue mix and the affiliates' focus on non-comp cost, we continue to expect the compensation ratio to fluctuate at around current levels. The compensation and benefits cost adjusted for the mark-to-market fluctuations increased 5%, and is in line with our expectations given the revenue growth we experienced. We had some additional severance expenses this quarter due to the ongoing review of our support functions and in line with our strategic priority to continually focus on cost and improve our operating margins.Slide 13 highlights the improvements we have made in our operating margins since our low point in the March of '09 quarter. Our margin this quarter was 18% on a GAAP basis, but includes a $28 million charge for the lease loss, which reduced our operating margin by 5.5 percentage points. As Mark has stated, a strategic priority of ours is to return our margins to levels we experienced in prior years.One of our primary strategic priorities has been to improve our balance sheet. And as you can see on Slide 14, we have a pro-forma representation of our sheet after the effect of the tax refund and debt repayment, and we have decreased our debt levels dramatically over the past 12 months, while increasing stockholders equity. So on a pro forma basis, cash and cash equivalents, which reflect the net impact of tax refund, as well as the $550 million debt reduction is $1.4 billion. We have also approximately $1 billion of excess cash that is available for strategic priorities and growth initiatives.Page 15 updates you on our bank covenants on a pro-forma basis, and you will see that the reduction of debt has meaningfully improved our ratios. Our gross leverage ratio falls to 2.7 times from 3.7 times. Net leverage improved to 1.2 times from 2.1 times, and our interest coverage jumped to 11.2 times. So we are clearly pleased with the progress we've made in improving our balance sheet strength over the past six months, continuing to generate strong cash earnings that will bolster our cash position and provide his continued flexibility.  With that, I will turn it back to Mark for closing comments.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, C.J. And before I open up to questions, I want to, as we've done in the past, just summarize our progress against our five key initiatives. In terms of balance sheet, C.J., really, has covered it. I think we've made very strong progress in paying
componenttext: Thanks, C.J. And before I open up to questions, I want to, as we've done in the past, just summarize our progress against our five key initiatives. In terms of balance sheet, C.J., really, has covered it. I think we've made very strong progress in paying off the term loan. Applying the tax refund is part of that process and still emerging with approximately $1 billion of excess cash to reinvest in our business. Our debt-to-capital ratio is now 20%. Second priority, managing our costs, we're going to continue to expand our focus on costs and efficiencies while we pursue growth initiatives, with revenues expanding our operating margin, excluding the lease charge, continues to improve. Third, engaging with the affiliates on the performance and risk management and other strategic initiatives. And performance is improved strongly over the year. Our Americas and the international distribution teams are working more closely with the affiliates. I guess the key challenge this year, in particular, to show some real leverage in terms of helping us shift into inflows. Clearly, this is a long-term initiative in the sense that it takes time for affiliates to demonstrate to their clients the resilience of their investment story. But we can expedite that process by working more closely together. We are also working with our affiliates on other ways to enhance their overall franchise. Fourth, in terms of basic distribution focus and product innovation, you can see net sales improving, and our Domestic business over year-over-year and our international long-term story has been very strong in terms of long-term funds year-over-year being strongly positive. This relates to our fifth initiative of looking tactically. It lifted out a bulk of [ph] opportunities. We have been busy this quarter and closed a couple of deals, but we did not conclude any basic lead on price discipline and fit. And we'll continue to apply those disciplines, going forward. With that, I'd like to open it up for questions. Both C.J. and I look forward to responding.

componenttextpreview: Obviously, that's perhaps the key issue of the story this quarter. I mean, we worked closely with Jim Hirschmann and team at Western. What we try to be is really fact-based. There's definitely been a seasonality experience. We actually went back and track
componenttext: Obviously, that's perhaps the key issue of the story this quarter. I mean, we worked closely with Jim Hirschmann and team at Western. What we try to be is really fact-based. There's definitely been a seasonality experience. We actually went back and tracked this over the last four years at Western. So there's an element of that. Number two is the enhanced cash story is one that has been industry-wide coming out of the prices. And there, we've taken something, it was $20 billion down to $3 billion. And this last big slug from the one client has happened. So there's, mathematically, less there to contribute to outflows. Beyond that, it's really kind of candidly pluses and minuses, it's blocking and tackling against Western, which I think has done a superb job over the last quarter, in particular, getting in front of clients, reaffirming mandates that they have, making aware of capabilities, particularly in these more specialized trends that I seem. And Jim and his team sees with clients that Western can deliver on that. And here, the pluses are meaningful. The global credit assets that have been raised globally, the currency business as done a number of different markets utilizing currency from other desks has been, I think, actually a [Audio Gap] development, and in the global tips area. On the other side, you can see some things that I think are cutting across. We managed the largest bond fund in Asia, in Japan. And there, there's just been a shift away. It's a global sovereign fund, and we shifted away from that into some other areas, some of which we're competing for. So I think that's it. The two key things, the seasonality and the enhanced cash, are mathematically the contributors. We don't see that continuing and beyond that, I know it's Western's belief that we look forward to kind of removing the remaining outflows and moving in inflows over the next couple quarters.

We've made a lot of progress on that, but more progress can be done to the extent. And I think all of us in the business, while we've had, particularly in the equity markets roughly second half of '09, a big pickup. I don't make anybody's bet in the ranch on market alone, nor should you ever do that in this business. So what I come in to '10 with is the real determination around us working together. LM and the affiliates to keep adding value in terms of some further efficiencies. We haven't put a number on that yet, Bill, and to the extent we get to a point where we should we will and we'll reach out to everybody.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have another question related to expenses. But Mark mentioned with Permal working with them on some new products initiatives and what not. And I'm just curious, I mean how have you all change on how you allocate costs that you incur to the various affil
componenttext: I have another question related to expenses. But Mark mentioned with Permal working with them on some new products initiatives and what not. And I'm just curious, I mean how have you all change on how you allocate costs that you incur to the various affiliates when you work alongside of them? My perception is that in the past, one of the issues that the holding company level may have been that you were kind of underpricing the services you provide so to speak to a lot of the affiliates. Can you maybe talk a little bit what kind of changes you've made in that, so that is, a Legg Mason shareholder you feel like, given the revenue-sharing arrangements, more of those costs are being born by the affiliates who benefit from that revenue growth?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it has been certainly over my tenure. A clear desire to get to essentially market-based service levels and service compensation for what we do. We clearly to the end -- and if you go back to our model slide, which we don't have this deck but
componenttext: Yes, I think it has been certainly over my tenure. A clear desire to get to essentially market-based service levels and service compensation for what we do. We clearly to the end -- and if you go back to our model slide, which we don't have this deck but we should always have every deck to remind us it's kind of basically affiliate investing plus LM distribution and servicing, plus what we do in terms of capital allocation, deliver shareholder value. And we're looking more closely with the affiliates on that distribution and that servicing fees and how we can be most efficient and effective in that. And so if you just use your example on the Permal situation, we're able to provide a service because of what we're already doing in our fund administration area, it's advantageous for them but it's also cost-effective for us. The bottom line, that should be accretive to the shareholder.

componenttext: If I can follow-up with questions on money funds. I just wanted to get -- I think there was a -- one of the comments was that future fee wavers could be less than a penny. Could you kind of bring us up to speed on what the current impact of fee waivers in the quarter just past four[ph]? headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll hit the impact. The impact really is quite negligible. It's less than a couple of pennies in total. Because from the fee waiver, we share that with a third-party distributor. And then when your revenue share effect and tax-effected, it really gets do
componenttext: I'll hit the impact. The impact really is quite negligible. It's less than a couple of pennies in total. Because from the fee waiver, we share that with a third-party distributor. And then when your revenue share effect and tax-effected, it really gets down to a negligible number. But in total, for the quarter, you could be talking a penny and a half, two pennies in total. And so we don't expect that to increase meaningfully in the next quarters but we do expect it to continue.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Rob let me pick up on the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney situation. As we talked about there, we have a very strong relationship with the leadership team there, and continue to be in active engagement on a number of product interactions. They've made no
componenttext: And Rob let me pick up on the Morgan Stanley Smith Barney situation. As we talked about there, we have a very strong relationship with the leadership team there, and continue to be in active engagement on a number of product interactions. They've made no final decisions around kind of managers that will continue in what form. One thing to point out is the big issue here cuts across the industry is a shift out of money funds into kind of bank deposit programs and bank products for a variety of reasons. And so today, right now, just to give you a kind of a fact update, we've got about 25 billion in retail liquidity funds with Morgan Stanley, that's down from 37 December of '08. That's consistent with I think others have experienced to have sweep vehicles in big brokerage dealers. So we're going to continue to work with them. It's less of an issue, but one that we hope we can work out favorably. But as I've also said, it's also depending on pricing which is going to be another issue, I suspect as well.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Can you give us an update on Permal in terms of the flows this quarter? And it just seems like that business is starting to turn, but what would be your thoughts as far as kind of a near-term flow picture? And then maybe from a longer-term standpoint, in terms of margins kind of talk about the interchange of fixed income versus equity and the influence to margins over time.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Permal and the update, the key shift that's going on there to a certain extent, multi-manager to single manager. And in the institutional channel kind of manage product to separate account, both of which, Permal is very well positioned for because of thei
componenttext: Permal and the update, the key shift that's going on there to a certain extent, multi-manager to single manager. And in the institutional channel kind of manage product to separate account, both of which, Permal is very well positioned for because of their access to the key managers and their ability to kind of put these products together very, very effectively. Specifically, what they've seen is a pickup in sales in the single manager area. Not as much pickup yet in the multi-manager area, both of which are going to have to happen to bring the kind of space back but they are encouraged. As we mentioned earlier, in Asia in particular, there's been a quicker recovery if you will, and they're making some real progress there. As you know, the relative performance of Permal is quite strong. And I think perhaps even more important, on top of that, the fact is their behavior through the difficult period with distribution partners and with clients, bodes very well for them, being an even stronger leader in this space going forward.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second question around margin and the various managers, we clearly get back to the margin in the thirties by getting more assets into the equity area where we tend to have higher fee, higher-margin situations. And we clearly are directing our activiti
componenttext: The second question around margin and the various managers, we clearly get back to the margin in the thirties by getting more assets into the equity area where we tend to have higher fee, higher-margin situations. And we clearly are directing our activities towards that and want to see that happen. Permal will also be an important contributor in that. As you can see, our second-largest contributor at the moment.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: On the Permal though, it sounds like sales are starting to pick up. Why would there continue to be kind of drips [ph of outflows at this point?

componenttext: The outflows basically, it's the classic case of the outflows continue, the sales really fell off. The sales have come back but not enough to offset what is a reduced, and what we've said is kind of pre-Lehman level of redemption. And I think some of this was some year-end stuff as well.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Cynthia Mayer of Bank of America.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: I guess just backing up on the margin question. I think in November you had an operating margin goal in the thirties, and I'm wondering if that's still your goal? And what are the main leverage you see that will just take you there? Is it the mix shift in equity you talked about or greater contribution for Permal or cost cuts or something else? can you order the factors in terms of the contribution you'd expect?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Cynthia. It's still very much our goal. I think in light of the fact to put it on the table that kind of recovery into inflows is taking a bit longer. I'm basically kind of gearing up the team, both the LM team and the affiliate team to see what more
componenttext: Yes, Cynthia. It's still very much our goal. I think in light of the fact to put it on the table that kind of recovery into inflows is taking a bit longer. I'm basically kind of gearing up the team, both the LM team and the affiliate team to see what more we can do to contribute to that, in addition to what we believe will come in terms of inflows. We will come in terms of a continued shift to equity and alternatives. So it's all of those things. But I think what you should here right now is a renewed focus on what we can do separate from the revenue line if you will.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: That's both the cash and the liquidity funds, both of which contributed international. The enhanced cash excuse me.

componenttext: Our next question comes from my Mike Carrier of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: One more question on the efficiencies and the expenses. When you look at how Legg Mason is organized with the affiliates, if you look at the costs that are currently centralized versus that's not. What areas, like obviously the compensation agreements tha
componenttext: One more question on the efficiencies and the expenses. When you look at how Legg Mason is organized with the affiliates, if you look at the costs that are currently centralized versus that's not. What areas, like obviously the compensation agreements that's going to be tough to change. The management of the affiliates that's going to be tough to change given the entrepreneurial nature of the divisions. When you look at whether it's trading back office, marketing and distribution. I guess what are the areas where there may be potential and maybe not now but down the road, if you kind of re-examine how the operations are structured?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you just go back to the progress we've made. I think when we first started very much as everyone in the industry did in response to the severe reduction in assets and revenues coming through the troubles. We took corporate overhead from a 600 plus
componenttext: I think you just go back to the progress we've made. I think when we first started very much as everyone in the industry did in response to the severe reduction in assets and revenues coming through the troubles. We took corporate overhead from a 600 plus to approximately 450, and we're now at 450 on a base of roughly 700 billion of assets. That has not been picking up as quickly as I would like. Hence, we can revisit that 450 and that comprised of across-the-board distribution, shared services and the ops and technology area, HR, Legal, Finance, et cetera. But in addition to that as was mentioned earlier, some of that is dedicated to services we provide the affiliates. And we're actively engaging with them as we have throughout this process on how to do that as efficiently as we can for the shareholder, while still adhering to a service level that delivers good effectiveness to the clients.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just the other thing, and I think you hit on this, on the commentary. But just given the progress that you've made on the balance sheet and the current leverage ratio, and then the excess cash, you mentioned some stuff on the M&A side. Just when
componenttext: And then just the other thing, and I think you hit on this, on the commentary. But just given the progress that you've made on the balance sheet and the current leverage ratio, and then the excess cash, you mentioned some stuff on the M&A side. Just when you look at everything that you have with all the affiliates, what are you looking in terms of filling? Obviously, you can't be too specific but in general where do you see gaps, where do you think you can build skill?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been very consistent on the international equity area. We've also worked with a number of our affiliates where certain list out opportunities could gel very well with their existing franchise. But I have to kind of underscore some of the thing
componenttext: Well, we've been very consistent on the international equity area. We've also worked with a number of our affiliates where certain list out opportunities could gel very well with their existing franchise. But I have to kind of underscore some of the things that we look at and chose not to do, is with some continued pricing discipline and a recognition that our currency right now, we believe, I believe is undervalued. And so that is as further discipline to what we should be doing. If you just take a look at I think we're kind of low-end in the peer group on a multiple visa [ph] and low-end of the peer group on basic enterprise value to AUM. This would all underscore, there's a lot of value in what we're doing and that represents other options as well.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: I'm going to let CJ handle that. But I do want to underscore the delight I have been talking about being paid performance fees by our clients, which underscores proof positive that our performance is picking up.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, as you know, December has typically been the quarter in which we have the most opportunity to achieve performance fees. I think the good news is that the majority of the performance fees we did earn this quarter were quarterly although 10 million we
componenttext: Mark, as you know, December has typically been the quarter in which we have the most opportunity to achieve performance fees. I think the good news is that the majority of the performance fees we did earn this quarter were quarterly although 10 million were annual measurement points. So it was split between Western and Permal. Obviously, Western had strong performance and they were delighted to earn performance fees. And Permal continues to have strong performance after now hitting the high-water mark on 75% of the assets. Permal is encouraged that they can continue to achieve some level of performance fees. So for modeling purposes, historically, we've been running around 10 million, we'd hope to do a little better than that. And our expectation would be somewhere 10 million to 20 million a quarter, although that obviously is very dependent upon continued performance.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about just what extent, is there a seasonality issue in performance fee calendar year end versus the kind of calendar quarter...
componenttext: Can you talk about just what extent, is there a seasonality issue in performance fee calendar year end versus the kind of calendar quarter...

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Performance fees are really client specific for the most part. And as you can imagine, there's a high number of those. It's really hard to give some sort of general. But the majority of at least in Permal, the majority that 75%, it set [ph] a high-water m
componenttext: Performance fees are really client specific for the most part. And as you can imagine, there's a high number of those. It's really hard to give some sort of general. But the majority of at least in Permal, the majority that 75%, it set [ph] a high-water mark, our quarterly contracts. So the good news is that we would expect a little less seasonality, although we could get to next December. And if performance continues to be strong, those annual performance fees could kick in and be accretive. So because of the individual nature of the performance fees and the number of them, it really is hard to generalize.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Mark, just in terms of Western and what's happening in Core? I think it's still your biggest product, what are you seeing on that front-end? And are we potentially heading into a period where maybe clients are going to be revisiting the way they
componenttext: And then Mark, just in terms of Western and what's happening in Core? I think it's still your biggest product, what are you seeing on that front-end? And are we potentially heading into a period where maybe clients are going to be revisiting the way they think about Core and there could be some more outflows on the comp [ph] there?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the net of this quarter versus prior quarters relative to Core and Core Plus is really positive. This year of strong performance where Western is delivering the client exactly as they should. They continued to make prudent credit that's where in p
componenttext: I think the net of this quarter versus prior quarters relative to Core and Core Plus is really positive. This year of strong performance where Western is delivering the client exactly as they should. They continued to make prudent credit that's where in prior years that wasn't working. They stayed true to that philosophy and delivered. There are other managers, it wasn't the case during this sea change if you will. So in that regard, I think Western is better positioned. Yes there's still some clients that, to be experienced, we saw as a seasonal uptick, took some money off the table. We see that less of an issue, but there's still some clients out there that are probably pondering but we're in a much better position in responding in that situation. On the flip side, and this I think is a definite inflection point is we are being invited into and competing for and actually it won some of those. And so you can imagine some clients who pulled the trigger, sometime in the first half of the year, probably regretting that given the strong performance throughout the year.

Or do you think there's additional capital that's going to be coming in the system in general?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's all about kind of going forward as all of us, as investors are conscious of. And on a go forward basis, while the money coming in to fixed is probably going to be less than has happened. And we have suffered some opportunity costs because of
componenttext: I think it's all about kind of going forward as all of us, as investors are conscious of. And on a go forward basis, while the money coming in to fixed is probably going to be less than has happened. And we have suffered some opportunity costs because of Western's challenges. There are actually very -- They're better positioned to participate in what remains which will be strong. In addition to that, we think we got strong offerings in the equity and alternatives to capture that. So I think we are well-positioned, which goes back to my strategic enthusiasm for our model and our managers in particular.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Hecht of JMP.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question is sounds like you guys are doing a good job managing down expenses, working to leverage distribution, clean up the balance sheet. But the outflow number of 33 billion, I mean still running at substantial levels. So I think you
componenttext: I guess the first question is sounds like you guys are doing a good job managing down expenses, working to leverage distribution, clean up the balance sheet. But the outflow number of 33 billion, I mean still running at substantial levels. So I think you guys have to be thinking outside the box in terms of what you can do to improve your top line or maybe unlock value in some ways. I guess the question is are you getting any incremental pressure from some of your investors like KKR and Nelson Peltz, given the heavy outflow story. There are certain acquisitions that may accelerate your fundamental improvement or disposition you'd consider to unlock value.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our investors, including in those two cases board members, are as concerned as I about the uptick in outflows, but really probably less than your question would suggest it's a challenge. We couldn't be happy about it, but if you really look
componenttext: Well, I think our investors, including in those two cases board members, are as concerned as I about the uptick in outflows, but really probably less than your question would suggest it's a challenge. We couldn't be happy about it, but if you really look underneath it, first off, it's still half the level of outflows year-over-year. And if you really go into the fixed income situation, I think you see some non-recurring aspects to it. And that's underneath, very much improved performance. And so I think what the board and the management team are focused on, now is the time to take this improved performance, unite with our distribution capabilities and really work harder. And on that regard, we will be thinking outside of the box, on how to kind of deploy our collective resources against that. In addition, I think because we've made the improvements we have on balance sheet, because we've made improvements in margin with more to be secured for sure, it gives us optionality on other considerations in terms of deploying capital. I would say the clear sentiment is let's focus on the 700 billion of assets that we have and make that as productive as we can, and rewarding as we can to our shareholders.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010

componenttext: On the tax rate, we're pretty consistent. But our expectation remains around the range that has been the last two, three quarters?

componenttext: What I want to do is kind of dissect sales and redemptions. Management has been talking about how better are the activity now for about two [ph] quarters. So I'm wondering did Western non-money market sales really go up in the December quarter from the September quarter. And then on redemption, can you quantify maybe you did this already but I'm sorry if I missed it, the one or two largest redemptions and maybe qualify how unusual they are?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes sales did go up. And so the net outflow story is what we believe to be particularly in the fixed income, not to be confused with liquidity breakout that we give. A couple of one-off situations in particular, Craig, was a $5 billion outflow of an enhan
componenttext: Yes sales did go up. And so the net outflow story is what we believe to be particularly in the fixed income, not to be confused with liquidity breakout that we give. A couple of one-off situations in particular, Craig, was a $5 billion outflow of an enhanced cash clients that we knew was going to be happening as has been happening across the space. That takes that category from $20 billion year end '08, down to three. And so there's less, mathematically, just less there to be happening. And on the RFP activity, I think I have to qualify what you said a bit. We have not seen nor have we just talked about and pickup in RFP activities in the areas where Western is seeing it now. The areas of Core, Core Plus because of their improved performance where they were on the bench. Now they're getting more active in new business opportunities and winning some of those. And I think clients who did terminate them are back in discussions because of the delivery of improved performance, and because of the long-term relationship Western has with these clients and their consultants. So I think that's how we respond.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Listen, I want to wrap up by thanking everyone and I want to speak first and foremost to our clients. Our performance has improved and we will continue to work hard together with our affiliates to not only continue that improved performance, but also to s
componenttext: Listen, I want to wrap up by thanking everyone and I want to speak first and foremost to our clients. Our performance has improved and we will continue to work hard together with our affiliates to not only continue that improved performance, but also to stay close to our clients through these still a bit choppy markets. From our shareholders, we believe strongly that Legg Mason is a franchise, it's undervalued. We're going to do all that we can to improve in the area specifically of growth and outflows and the inflows and improved margin. And as one caller said, think outside of the box to do that on any and every front that can make sense. We look forward to working and delivering for our shareholders and we thank all of you who follow us after your questions. Thank you.

componenttext: Thank you, Amy. On behalf of Legg Mason, I would like to welcome you to our conference call to discuss operating results for the fiscal 2010 third quarter ended December 31, 2009. This presentation may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements are not statements of facts or guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed in these statements.For a discussion of these risks and uncertainties, please see risk factors and management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and the results of operations in the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2009, and in the company's quarterly reports on Form 10-Q.This morning's call will include remarks from Mark Fetting, our Chairman and CEO; and Mr. CJ Daley, our CFO, who will discuss Legg Mason's financial results. In addition, following a review of the company's quarter, we will then open the call to Q&A. Now I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Mark Fetting. Mark?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. In 2009, we initiated a turnaround at Legg Mason, and I am pleased with most of our progress. Our balance sheet is much stronger, investment performance has improved across virtually all key affiliates, and
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us. In 2009, we initiated a turnaround at Legg Mason, and I am pleased with most of our progress. Our balance sheet is much stronger, investment performance has improved across virtually all key affiliates, and our focus on distribution is paying some market share dividends.2010 was kicked off here in Baltimore with all of our key sales teams and our investment managers coming together to start the new year strong. We are ready to take advantage of opportunities this year. But to be clear, more progress needs to be made in restoring growth and improving margins. As we look at the markets, we believe general trends should show a gradual move in assets from money market funds and taxable fixed income to equities and alternatives as the credit market stall further and as investors' risk appetite increase. In the wake of the rally of the most-beaten-down stocks in '09, many of our equity managers in the U.S. see the most value and the greatest opportunity in high-quality companies with strong balance sheets, steady earnings and high returns on capital. Our team at Western [Western Asset Management] believes that a slow recovery in the economy will continue in the first half of 2010. Housing prices seem to have bottomed, unemployment shows signs of moderating and production is coming back online to meet demand.Continued challenges with some balance sheet issues and budget issues and state and local governments continue to draw a caution, but by in large, Western still sees value in the market. The alternative sector went to a significant clean-up period last year. And the remaining players are stronger. Investors have become more comfortable with the sector, as there is now more transparency and generally less leverage being applied. Permal, our fund of hedge funds manager, has seen more interest from high net worth in institutional clients, with Asia being a particularly attractive opportunity. Strategically, as I look forward for Legg Mason in our global asset management industry, I am very encouraged, particularly by the visits with clients, consultants and distribution partners I had over the last quarter across the globe: In Europe, in Asia and throughout the Americas. I believe clients are all about more scrutiny, more due diligence, an increased appreciation for specialized skills for specialized mandates. Yes, there is an important shift in passive and ETF, some of which I believe is cyclical coming out of the crisis, and some are secular, which we'll have to follow and potentially participate in. But active remains the dominant choice, and this bodes well for our franchise firms.Western's scale and specialization skill set, Royce's expertise in small and micro-cap investing Permal's preeminence in fund of hedge funds, Legg Mason Capital Management in ClearBridge and large-cap U.S. equities among other specializations and Batterymarch and Brandywine. So with that as a backdrop, let's turn to the financial highlights onto the deck that we distributed this morning. Let's start with Page 2.As you can see, revenues are up 5% over the last quarter to $690 million, primarily due to higher performance fees at Western and Permal, higher average assets under management and a greater percentage of equity assets in our mix. Operating income, as adjusted, was $92 million as higher revenues were more than offset by the previously disclosed $28 million real estate lease charge for our sub-leasing efforts. Our operating margin, as adjusted this quarter, was 17.9%. The impact of the real estate lease charge on the operating margin, as adjusted, was 5.5%. So excluding the effect of the accelerated charge for subleasing all of our excess space in our headquarters, operating margin would've been up a couple of percentage points. Net income was almost $45 million or $0.28 a share, which includes $0.11 for the real estate. Cash income on an adjusted basis was $93 million or $0.57 per diluted share. EBITDA, as adjusted, was $165 million, up 20% from the prior-quarter level.Let's take a look at Assets Under Management as we turn to Slide 3. Here, as you can see and as we discussed early in December, there is a pick up in outflows. Assets Under Management were $682 billion, down from the $703 billion in September, driven by the higher outflows and partially offset by market appreciation. Equity assets are a higher percentage of the total mix at 25%. This is the highest level since September quarter of '08. Average AUM was up in the third quarter as compared with the previous, just over 1%.Let's turn to Slide 4 in the key issue of net flows. As reported and discussed earlier, there was an uptick in the December quarter, driven by year-end reallocation decisions made by investors. Some took advantage of the strong performance rebound across several of our affiliates to make changes. Fixed income outflows for the quarter were approximately $24 billion. Equity increased to $4 billion and liquidity were $5 billion out. You will recall that last quarter we had positive liquidity flows of $4 billion in a quarter where the industry had record outflows. This quarter, we were slightly better than the industry outflow trend. In the fixed income area, some investors who earlier in the year had been assessing the risk they had in their fixed income portfolios did take advantage of a sharply stronger performance in the calendar year and made a change. In addition, Western experiences a fair amount of seasonality in the December quarter. And as we've mentioned before, investors are moving out of the enhanced cash area in particular. To be clear and specific, there is a single client representing about $5 billion of that outflows in the enhanced cash area, something that we hadn't [ph] been expecting for some time. And that area which was over $20 billion, just a bit more than a year ago, is now down to $3 billion and this is consistent with the industry experience across the board.If you kind of acknowledge the enhanced cash situation and look at other areas, you'll see, really, individual asset-allocation decisions across the globe. There was a bit of a moving out of limited-duration portfolios, particularly those that use spread products that were part of the process. But overall, what we see is, really, clearly some issues that we've been talking about and an expectation of some lumpiness, but at the same time, as we'll discuss, some good activity on the upbeat.So let's turn, if we can, to our affiliates. The reminder, and this is on Slide 5, as we've done in the past, we're listing the affiliates in the order of their contribution to earnings. So let's focus on Western first, our largest manager, with $481 billion under management. We do see the outflows continuing to be an issue, but we do think that this quarter, because of the seasonality and some of the specific client situations, may not be projectable. Important to Western returning to net inflows will be continued strong performance and the continued decrease of volatility in the fixed income markets. We do see an uptick in RFP activity, and while there's always a lag between activity inflows, that is encouraging. We absolutely see continued interest in the Brazilian, Australian, Pan Asian local currency products, their emerging market debt products, their global credit products and global tips.Most importantly, clients are pleased with how the additions to the investment and risk management teams have taken place. And Western believes that the changes they have made in their investment process are working well. And as we've discussed, their performance has been strong this year.Let's go to Permal where assets were slightly lower at almost $18 billion. Performance at Permal is strong across the board, with 75% of their asset subject to performance fees above their high-water mark. Permal is one of the industry players poised to serve the growing separate account market in the alternative space. Legg Mason is providing Permal with an increased level of back-office support, representing a good example of how our affiliates can leverage our corporate infrastructure.Next is ClearBridge, our largest equity affiliate, who saw assets increase to $53.5 billion. ClearBridge is seeing some initial interest in the strategies from the family and high net worth offices, and are embarking on a comprehensive road show with our wholesalers to the independent advisor channel this quarter as they continue to see greater penetration in new channels. In December, ClearBridge was selected by Pax World and Morningstar as the sub-advisor across four asset classes in their new socially-responsible offerings. Assets at Royce grew to just over $30 billion. They continue to see inflows this quarter amidst continued strong performance across the complex. Brandywine, assets were about $29 billion with modest outflows for the quarter. Fixed income performance here rebounded nicely, and their flagship global fixed income investment grade product is ahead of its benchmark over the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods, and we continue to work with Brandywine to source new opportunities through our sales team, one institutional mandate for the large-cap value equity product funded in the quarter, and another one in the quarter funded last week, both of these totaling over $300 million. Brandywine is also seeking client wins in Japan, working with the LM Japan office.Batterymarch was essentially flat at $20 billion. Batterymarch's global emerging markets product is seeing strong relative performance in the second half of '09 as the markets have moved from a rally in the most beaten down stocks to higher-quality names. Interest in the product is building among consultants. Finally, Legg Mason Capital Management assets were up slightly to about $17 billion with continued strong performance. Four of their six mutual funds had top decile performance for the year, and all six were top quartile according to Lipper. Legg Mason Capital Management had modest inflows into their offshore funds, an important [indiscernible], some outflow in the U.S. funds, and institutional clients are inviting them back into RFPs.If you shift to Slide 6 with focus on long-term performance. You can see, clearly, the progress we have made this year with regard to performance and how that is playing into our longer-term numbers. Over two-thirds of our long-term fund assets are beating their benchmark over the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods. If you go to Slide 7, you can look at the break out between equity and fixed income. With equity, the performance has picked up in the one year, but especially in the three and five year. On fixed income, it is even more impressive with the fixed income funds in the top quartile for the one-year period, the funds are also beating the Lipper averages in the one-, three-, five- and 10-year periods, up from extremely low levels in those same periods a year ago.Let's shift if we can to distribution. Slide 8, you can see that net sales in our Americas distribution group shows improvement over a year-ago period, although we did see a reversal in flow trends this quarter as sub-advisory accounts, particularly in the variable annuity clients, made some decisions to shift to other asset classes. Growth sales, one measure of measuring our performance, are up sharply in Americas distribution. Retail funds sales against the prior year are strong and is actually at an all-time high in the very important independent advisory channel. Institutional sales were up over 40% as compared with the year-ago period. And as I mentioned previously, we're seeing some share gains in certain categories of funds, muni and equity in particular.We raised our third closed-end fund with Western this quarter. Raising $316 million in the global corporate fund, this was our largest closed-end fund offering during '09, where we had several strong product introductions.The retirement channel is going to be an important market for us. We will tap into our affiliate expertise and add to our existing income and dividend-generating products. We are launching an inflation aware tactical asset allocation program in February, designed to be not highly correlated to the broader markets, snd we think it will be very attractive for retirement portfolio.On Slide 9, we focused on international distribution, which showed continued improvement compared with the same period a year ago and at positive for the fiscal year. This was the best quarter in the last five of our International Distribution group led by Japan, where Legg Mason has been established the longest. We also saw net positive flows in Europe, the Americas and Asia this quarter. The majority of flows outside of the U.S. continue to be centered on fixed income in Western. The bulk of our net inflows on the equity side are going into Royce, Legg Mason Capital Management and Congruix, our Asian equity manager. We launched the Legg Mason Permal Global Absolute Fund in October and have subsequently registered it in Europe and Asia. So now I will give it to C.J. to cover the financial issues. C.J.?

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Mark indicated, we're continuing to see improved trends in investment performance, which resulted in higher revenues this quarter, primarily performance fees. So in December, revenues grew 5% from the September
componenttext: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Mark indicated, we're continuing to see improved trends in investment performance, which resulted in higher revenues this quarter, primarily performance fees. So in December, revenues grew 5% from the September quarter as a result of higher average AUMs, and as I mentioned, a substantial pick up in performance fees. On the expense side, we recorded the entire sublease charge for our headquarters of $28 million that we announced on the call last quarter. Although we did expect that the charge would come in over several quarters, we were able to complete all the sublease transactions this quarter, so we took the entire $28 million charge that we had highlighted last quarter. That charge reduced our reported diluted earnings by $28 million or $0.11 per share.In addition, subsequent to the end of the quarter, as anticipated after the net operating loss, tax law changed to allow us to put tax losses back five years instead of three. We received a tax refund in early January of $459 million, which increased our total cash position to $1.9 billion and our excess cash to $1.5 billion. With that excess cash, we announced today that we paid down $550 million term loan, which was scheduled to mature in October of 2010 this year. The reduction of the outstanding debt will lower our annual interest expense by approximately $15 million or $0.06 per share.So let's move on to the investor deck on Slide 10. Our GAAP earnings per share were $0.28 per share or $45 million, and that includes $28 million in real estate lease loss charges that we took. Cash income, as adjusted, was $0.57 per share or $93 million and also reflects the impact of the lease losses. Cash income was higher this quarter, but on a per-share basis, was slightly lower due to a higher share count this quarter related to the equity unit exchanges that we completed in August.Our operating margin, as adjusted, was 18%, down from 21% last quarter. The lease charge impact on the operating margin was 5.5 percentage points. The margin improvement, excluding lease loss was a result of higher revenues, particularly performance fees, with relatively flat operating expense.Operating revenues for the quarter were $690.5 million, an increase of 5%, primarily due to the higher performance fees at Western and Permal, and as well as higher Assets Under Management in the quarter. As we discussed it last quarter's call, we continue to see modest increases in fee waivers required in our Money Fund business, and we expect this to continue into the next several quarters. For modeling, our expectation is that any increase in waivers for the next quarter would only be a few million dollars grossed or less than $0.01 a share.Moving on to Slide 11, to break out our operating expenses, we're up 5%. But the entire increase, as you can see, is driven by the lease charge. Excluding that item, total expenses were essentially flat compared to the prior quarter. Comp and benefits expensed for $288 million in both the December and September quarters, while the increase in distribution and servicing expense was the result of successful global fixed income closed-end fund launch this quarter and the related expenses of about $4.3 million.Occupancy expense increase was driven by the real estate charge related to our headquarters built. With the finalization of the subleasing of our headquarters' vacant space, we have now either reserved or sublet at all of our excess space. Strategically, we have moved aggressively on while reserving and subletting our excess space. And as a result, beginning next quarter, because of our headquarters' sublease completion, our occupancy cost will be down approximately $800,000 per quarter or $3.2 million per year. This is in addition to savings of $300,000 we received this quarter, as we realized the partial period of the headquarters' sublease benefits. All the remaining expense categories showed improvement over the sequential quarter due to our continued focus on cost maintenance and discipline.On Slide 12, we highlight our compensation and benefits expenses expressed as a percentage of net revenues, which are operating in revenues less our distribution servicing expenses to third parties. Our compensation ratio of 53% is slightly lower than last quarter's level due to our higher revenues and our cost discipline. With the current revenue mix and the affiliates' focus on non-comp cost, we continue to expect the compensation ratio to fluctuate at around current levels. The compensation and benefits cost adjusted for the mark-to-market fluctuations increased 5%, and is in line with our expectations given the revenue growth we experienced. We had some additional severance expenses this quarter due to the ongoing review of our support functions and in line with our strategic priority to continually focus on cost and improve our operating margins.Slide 13 highlights the improvements we have made in our operating margins since our low point in the March of '09 quarter. Our margin this quarter was 18% on a GAAP basis, but includes a $28 million charge for the lease loss, which reduced our operating margin by 5.5 percentage points. As Mark has stated, a strategic priority of ours is to return our margins to levels we experienced in prior years.One of our primary strategic priorities has been to improve our balance sheet. And as you can see on Slide 14, we have a pro-forma representation of our sheet after the effect of the tax refund and debt repayment, and we have decreased our debt levels dramatically over the past 12 months, while increasing stockholders equity. So on a pro forma basis, cash and cash equivalents, which reflect the net impact of tax refund, as well as the $550 million debt reduction is $1.4 billion. We have also approximately $1 billion of excess cash that is available for strategic priorities and growth initiatives.Page 15 updates you on our bank covenants on a pro-forma basis, and you will see that the reduction of debt has meaningfully improved our ratios. Our gross leverage ratio falls to 2.7 times from 3.7 times. Net leverage improved to 1.2 times from 2.1 times, and our interest coverage jumped to 11.2 times. So we are clearly pleased with the progress we've made in improving our balance sheet strength over the past six months, continuing to generate strong cash earnings that will bolster our cash position and provide his continued flexibility.  With that, I will turn it back to Mark for closing comments.

headline: Legg Mason Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, C.J. And before I open up to questions, I want to, as we've done in the past, just summarize our progress against our five key initiatives. In terms of balance sheet, C.J., really, has covered it. I think we've made very strong progress in paying
componenttext: Thanks, C.J. And before I open up to questions, I want to, as we've done in the past, just summarize our progress against our five key initiatives. In terms of balance sheet, C.J., really, has covered it. I think we've made very strong progress in paying off the term loan. Applying the tax refund is part of that process and still emerging with approximately $1 billion of excess cash to reinvest in our business. Our debt-to-capital ratio is now 20%. Second priority, managing our costs, we're going to continue to expand our focus on costs and efficiencies while we pursue growth initiatives, with revenues expanding our operating margin, excluding the lease charge, continues to improve. Third, engaging with the affiliates on the performance and risk management and other strategic initiatives. And performance is improved strongly over the year. Our Americas and the international distribution teams are working more closely with the affiliates. I guess the key challenge this year, in particular, to show some real leverage in terms of helping us shift into inflows. Clearly, this is a long-term initiative in the sense that it takes time for affiliates to demonstrate to their clients the resilience of their investment story. But we can expedite that process by working more closely together. We are also working with our affiliates on other ways to enhance their overall franchise. Fourth, in terms of basic distribution focus and product innovation, you can see net sales improving, and our Domestic business over year-over-year and our international long-term story has been very strong in terms of long-term funds year-over-year being strongly positive. This relates to our fifth initiative of looking tactically. It lifted out a bulk of [ph] opportunities. We have been busy this quarter and closed a couple of deals, but we did not conclude any basic lead on price discipline and fit. And we'll continue to apply those disciplines, going forward. With that, I'd like to open it up for questions. Both C.J. and I look forward to responding.

componenttextpreview: Obviously, that's perhaps the key issue of the story this quarter. I mean, we worked closely with Jim Hirschmann and team at Western. What we try to be is really fact-based. There's definitely been a seasonality experience. We actually went back and track
componenttext: Obviously, that's perhaps the key issue of the story this quarter. I mean, we worked closely with Jim Hirschmann and team at Western. What we try to be is really fact-based. There's definitely been a seasonality experience. We actually went back and tracked this over the last four years at Western. So there's an element of that. Number two is the enhanced cash story is one that has been industry-wide coming out of the prices. And there, we've taken something, it was $20 billion down to $3 billion. And this last big slug from the one client has happened. So there's, mathematically, less there to contribute to outflows. Beyond that, it's really kind of candidly pluses and minuses, it's blocking and tackling against Western, which I think has done a superb job over the last quarter, in particular, getting in front of clients, reaffirming mandates that they have, making aware of capabilities, particularly in these more specialized trends that I seem. And Jim and his team sees with clients that Western can deliver on that. And here, the pluses are meaningful. The global credit assets that have been raised globally, the currency business as done a number of different markets utilizing currency from other desks has been, I think, actually a [Audio Gap] development, and in the global tips area. On the other side, you can see some things that I think are cutting across. We managed the largest bond fund in Asia, in Japan. And there, there's just been a shift away. It's a global sovereign fund, and we shifted away from that into some other areas, some of which we're competing for. So I think that's it. The two key things, the seasonality and the enhanced cash, are mathematically the contributors. We don't see that continuing and beyond that, I know it's Western's belief that we look forward to kind of removing the remaining outflows and moving in inflows over the next couple quarters.
